article.title: Combined parametrization of the neutron electric form factor and the $γ^∗N →Δ(1232)$ quadrupole form factors

choices: The pion cloud contributions to G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub>.
The valence quark contributions to G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub>.
The total contributions (valence + pion cloud) to G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub>.
The experimental data for G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub>.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the two fits for G<sub>En</sub> presented in Figure 2?
choices: The dashed line fit includes valence quark contributions while the thin band fit does not.
The dashed line fit is a direct fit to G<sub>En</sub> data only, while the thin band fit is a global fit including G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub> data.
The dashed line fit is based on the Galster parametrization, while the thin band fit uses a rational function.
There is no significant difference between the two fits.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the comparison of the red and blue bands in Figure 3?
choices: The inclusion of valence quark contributions does not significantly impact the description of the quadrupole form factor data.
The global fit (blue band), which includes the valence quark contributions, provides a better description of the quadrupole form factor data compared to the fit without them (red band).
The model is unable to describe the G<sub>C</sub> data accurately.
The pion cloud contributions are negligible for Q<sup>2</sup> > 0.5 GeV<sup>2</sup>.

multiple_choice_question.text: What important physical principle is illustrated by the convergence of the G<sub>E</sub> and κG<sub>C</sub> curves near Q<sup>2</sup> = -0.09 GeV<sup>2</sup> in Figure 7?
choices: The dominance of pion cloud contributions at low Q<sup>2</sup>.
The validity of perturbative QCD at high Q<sup>2</sup>.
The importance of valence quark contributions to the quadrupole form factors.
Siegert's theorem, which relates G<sub>E</sub> and G<sub>C</sub> at the pseudothreshold.
